Articles.Content:
The idea is quite simple : a kind of notepad included as new part which should be readable and editable in VAB and in flight.

This should act as flight manual, describing some features as action groups, or giving some indications, as burn time for TMI for example.

Thanks for reading.

What are you interested in with this feature that isn't already provided by clicking on the ship's title and getting the little drop-down text pad? (out of curiosity - define the difference between that and what you're suggesting).

My thoughts exactly, this feature is provided already in the form of Ship description. and if you're putting a ship up for download that needs a manual, most people will upload a folder with the ship and a readme file that expalins how to work it.
Is there a way to view the description in-flight?

I do not believe so, but that's why we have a memory! or better, Pen and paper!

But seriously, that is a valid point there. the forgetfull may need info in-flight for how to operate their vessel.

Considering just how many action groups some of my crafts use it would be really helpful actually.

Even more so for SSTOs that needs to be flown a specific way to make it into orbit.

It would be really cool if it was a part of the cockpit exterior, either as a notebook or as a stickynote.
I'm pretty sure FAR adds something like this.
The B9 mod has an Info part that you could use to write notes for the craft it's attached to. And it can be set to open up as soon as the craft spawns.
The B9 thing was what I was thinking about, wrong mod .

This suggestion popped up a month or so ago

http://forum.kerbalspaceprogram.com/showthread.php/27428-place-to-type-text-notes-for-vehicles?highlight=flight+manual

And I still think it's great!

While I agree this is useful, I would like to say that I find its actually easier to just use pen and paper. Having an on-screen notepad is convenient, to an extent, but it blocks off part of the screen when you're using it (if not all the time, depending on implementation), and could potentially make things just a bit too cluttered and annoying for my liking :s

It could be useful, maybe, if you think about it.

If you leave the game for a while, then come back, it'd be nice to have a reminder of what you were planning on doing with the big hunks of space stuff you put into orbit last time you played.

As for action groups, that's not a bad thought either.

I use a memory technique, where certain things use certain ranges- for example, engine things are always towards the lower numbers, miscellaneous things are always near the end, and common features, like ladder deployment, always use standard buttons, even if they interrupt other groupings. It works so far.
